WILLIAM MALES , Jun. I was at the shop door—Ann Brady pointed out Marsh, and John Carthy to me—Brady gave me a bad sixpence—she took the bad one back and they gave her a good one—she brought it to me—the two young men went away together.

WILLIAM MALES , Sen. I live at Deptford, and am the father of the last witness. I recollect Mrs. Brady coming to my son for change for sixpence—I followed the two young men—I saw them first go to widow Townsend's, the baker's—one of them went it—I followed them after he came out, to the Black Horse Bridge, they were then joined by the prisoner Thomas Carthy—they then went towards Rotherhithe—I sent to William Badham, and he joined us at China-hall—when he joined us the three prisoners separated, and one went inside Mr. Mumford's shop—after he came out they fell into company again—they went two hundred yards and then went to a bun-shop—one went in—he came out and they joined again—I went into the bun-shop, came out, and followed them—I saw Marsh and John Carthy go into a pork-shop—Thomas Carthy did not go into any shop, to my knowledge—I still followed them over Mill-pond Bridge—I sent to the station-house that I wanted more assistance—they joined again after they got through St. James's-gate—we and the policeman then surrounded them, put them into a baker's-shop near Lilliput-hall, and took them to the station-house—I searched Thomas Carthy, and found on him four base sixpences, and 2s. 10 1/2d. in copper.

WILLIAM BADHAM . I am a police-constable. I joined Males in pur
suit of the prisoners—when they were taken, I saw Thomas Carthy stoop down, and do something to his left foot—when we got to the station-house, I examined him, and found three pieces of metal on him—three counter
feit sixpences fell from his shoe—I found a file and knife on John Carthy.
Thomas Marsh. There was no money tumbled from my shoe, but it fell from my jacket pocket.

JOSIAH PERCEVALL . I assisted in taking the prisoners—I searched Marsh, and found, 1s. 6d. in good silver, and 6 1/2d. in copper, and a dupli
cate.
WILLIAM PHIPPS . I am an inspector of police. I saw the shoe taken of Thomas Carthy—I heard something fall, and picked it up—it was three counterfeit sixpences.

JOHN FIELD . I am an inspector of coin to the Mint. These sixpences are all six counterfeit—four of them are unfinished—a file and knife would be useful to put them in a state for circulation—this white metal is the same as the money is made of—it is what we call the get—the other three six
pences
are also counterfeit, but the metal has been removed from the edges of them.

Charthy's Defence. We went to sell mats, and sold them to a wagoner, who gave us 4s. in half pence—we met this young man—he asked it we were going to London—we said yes, and he picked up this money and gave it me—I did not know whether it was good or bad—I put it into my waistcoat pocket with some copper.

Thomas Marsh's Defence. I picked up a rag, and in that was a paper, and in that seven bad sixpences—I gave them to Thomas Carthy, and we had not got three yards further before we picked up three pieces of metal, which Thomas Carthy took.

THOMAS CARTHY—
GUILTY . Aged 19.

JOHN CARTHY—
GUILTY . Aged 17.

THOMAS MARSH—
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Confined Eighteen Months.

p.hi: Fifth Jury, Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
2011.
GEORGE TEBBUTT was indicted
for embezzlement.
MR. CLARKSON conducted the Prosecution.

LEWIS GRAVE . I am in partnership with Mr. William Winterbourne—we are linen and woollen-drapers, in Blackman-street, Borough. The prisoner came into our service about March—we do the tally trade to a considerable extent, and are obliged to employ persons to make col
lections by the week—I have got the book that the prisoner kept in his travels—it was his duty to receive money on our account, and to enter it in this book, and account to me every night—his par
ticular days for collecting were Monday and Tuesday, and it was his duty to enter in this book, the sums received on each of the days mentioned, in this column from the person whose surname appears—there is no entry of 2s. from Mrs. Stubbs on the 5th of April; nor of 2s. from Mrs. Carpenter on the 16th of May, or the 27th of June—Stubbs' was a Tuesday's collection, and Carpenter's a Monday's—we have some of Mrs. Carpenter's bills which are in the book—it was the duty of the prisoner to enter on the back of each bill of parcels, the date and sum received by the week—on Mrs. Carpenter's bill there is a sum of 2s. on the 16th of May, and 27th of June, but they are not in the book, and he never accounted to me for them—the writing on the bills is his—on the 29th of June he did not come, and a letter was received by Mr. Winterbourne.

Prisoner. You say I received Stubbs' on Tuesday, it was on Wednes
day, because the round was too long.

ELIZA STUBBS . I am single, and live in Lambeth-place, West-square. I was in the habit of paying sums of money to the prisoner on account of his employers—he came sometimes on Tuesday, sometimes on Wednes
day—this is my bill—on the 5th of April, I paid him 2s., and here is his writing on the back of the bill at the time I paid it.
Prisoner. Q. When you paid me on the Wednesday morning, I dated it as if received on the Tuesday? A. Yes, you did.

SARAH CARPENTER . I am the wife of Edward Carpenter, of Adams-place, Rotherhithe. I had been in the habit of paying the prisoner, on account of his master, sums of money weekly for articles—on the 16th of May, Monday, I paid him 2s., he entered it on the back of the bill—on the 27th of June I paid him 2s., he entered that also on the back of the bill—I remember his coming to me on Sunday—I think it was in the

month of July—he told me his governor was coming on the Monday, and I was not to pay him, nor yet to give him any bill—I asked him what was the reason—he said he had had a bit of a spree, and he had spent his master's money; but in the course of a week or two he should be able to recover all that—I made him no answer—when my husband came home, I told him—his master called the next day—the prisoner came again on the Monday following, and gave me a new bill—the old bill contained as usual the indorsement on the back of it, showing the weekly sums re
ceived up to the 13th of June—in the old bill there appears to have been received 13s. 6d., and in the new bill there is cash received 11s. 6d., but I had paid him 13s. 6d.—he told me to destroy the old bill, there was no occasion to keep it—he did not ask me to give it him—he told me to burn it, it was no good—I showed it to my husband, and in consequence of what he told me, I kept both—he used to have such a red covered book as that in which he made his entries.
Prisoner. I told you there was an error in the bill of 2s.—I did not know where it was—I put down 2s., but you did not pay me that 2s. Witness. Yes, I did.

HENRY DOUGHTON WINTERBOURNE . I am in partnership with Mr. Grave. On Tuesday the 28th of June, it was the prisoner's duty to attend in the evening as usual with his collecting book—instead of coming, he sent a letter about half-past ten o'clock in the evening—I took no charge of the letter, and cannot find it—it was not in his handwriting—in consequence of what the letter contained, I went to his residence, No. 3, Crown-square, Borough—he was not there—according to the note, I expected to find him ill in bed—I found him in the street dancing with a pipe in his mouth—I did not let him know I saw him—he has not accounted to me for my of the sums that have been mentioned.
Prisoner. Q. Have not these sums been accounted for an paid in your books? A. They have not.

Prisoner's Defence. (written.) "My Lord, and gentleman of the Jury. Those deficiencies frequently occur in that tally trade, as I have upwards of 150 persons to call on every day; at the same time those amounts brought against me have been accounted for to my employers, excepting the two last sums of 4s. and 2s., which would have been placed to my account, as others were, at the end of the week; and they also agreed to charge me with those amounts, my having a small account open for goods had by my wife, and to be deducted at 3s. per week from my salary, which was regu
larly done up to the 25th of June, 1836."

GUILTY . Aged 34.—
Transported for Seven Years.
THERE WERE TWO OTHER INDICTMENTS AGAINST THE PRISONER.

2012.
THOMAS SUTCH was indicted
for stealing, on the 28th of June, 1 hammer, value 1s. 4d.; 2 pump-irons, value 2s. 6d.; 1 seat
iron, value 1s.; 1 fore-part iron, value 1s.; 1 strap, value 8d.; 1 knife, value 3d.; 4 awls, value 4d.1 long-stick, value 1 d.; 2 files, value 10d., 1 brush, value 2d.; 1 stirrup, value 3d.; 1 lap-iron, value 2d.; and the materials for a pair of uppers for shoes, value 1s. 3d.; the goods of
Thomas Lansbrough Drew, his master, and that he had ben before con
victed of felony.
THOMAS LANSBROUGH DREW . I live in Assembly-street, Blackfriar's-road, and am a shoemaker. The prisoner was my apprentice—I came

down on the morning of the 28th of June, at half-past five o'clock and he and the tools stated were gone—the prisoner was apprehended and brought to me by the officer, with these tools, on the 16th of July.
Prisoner. You know you ill-used me—I can show the marks—the tools were part of them mine. Witness The part that were his were taken away at Queen-square—the rest that are here are mine.
EDWARD JAMES LEVY (police-sergeant T 18.) I took the prisoner at Brentford—these tools were found in the room where he was at work—he said they were his.

THOMAS HOBBS (police-constable C 85.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—the pri
soner is the man—(read)
(John Sutch, the prisoner's uncle, gave him a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Transported For Fourteen Years.

p.hi: Sixth Jury, Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

div1.p:
2013.
CATHERINE NEALE was indicted
for stealing, on the 13th of July, 1 shift, value 1s., the goods of
Norah Shea: 2 caps, value 6s., the goods of
Mary Mack: 1 bonnet, value 6s.; 1 gown, value 7s.; 3 hand
kerchiefs, value 4s.; 1 waist-ribbon, value 6d.; the goods of
Ellen Carty: 8 yards of printed cotton, value 8s.; 1 apron, value 10d.; the goods of
Mary Connell: 1 gown, value 6d.; 1 petticoat, value 1s.; 1 pair of stock
ings, value 2s.; 1 pair of gloves, value 6d.; and 1 cap, value 6d.; the goods of
Ellen Rowan.

NORAH SHEA . I lost my shift from Mr. Biggs, a market-gardener, at Barnet—I had left it on line, over my bed—I slept in a barn there (I came over from Ireland two years ago) the prisoner worked there about three months—I found the shift on her person—I never lent it to her.
MARY MACK . I work for Mr. Biggs, and sleep in the same place—I missed two caps—the policeman has them—these are mine.

ELLEN CARTY . I worked for Mr. Biggs three or four years—I slept in the same barn—I lost a bonnet, a gown, three handkerchiefs, and a waist
ribbon—these are mine.

MARY CONNELL . I worked for Mr. Biggs, and slept in the barn—I lost a gown-piece and apron—these are them—I never lent them to the pri
soner—I only had this gown-piece from about one o'clock on Tuesday till the Wednesday night, when I lost it.
ELLEN ROWAN . I worked in the same place. I missed a gown, a petticoat, cap, and gloves—these are them—I kept them in the barn over my bed on a line—I never lent them to the prisoner.

MARGARET KIRWAN . I live on Ealing-common, near the Uxbridge-road, and keep a house to accommodate travellers. I have no sign up—the prisoner came there on Wednesday night, and brought this property—the policeman took her on the Sunday morning.
JOHN PASCOE (police-sergeant I 19.) I found some of this property of Kirwan's some on the prisoner's person, and I found a duplicate of some of it on her.
JOHN ALDOUS . I am a pawnbroker at Hammersmith. This gown and gown-piece were pawned at my house—I don't know by whom, but this duplicate was given for it.
Prisoner. I asked to borrow a gown and handkerchief—I was going
to see a friend—we were always in the habit of lending to each other any thing we had.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2014.
THOMAS WHEELER was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of August, 1 purse, value 2d.; 1 sixpence, and 7 pence, and 7 half-pence, the goods and monies of
Charles Simpson, from the person of
Rebecca Simpson; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

REBECCA SIMPSON . I am the wife of Charles Simpson, of Brothers-row, Lambeth. On the 1st of August I was at Lambeth-stairs, looking at the rowing match, and had a red purse in my pocket containing the money stated—a gentleman came and told me something—I was my purse on the ground—a gentleman seized the prisoner—this is my purse—it has the money in it now.

GEORGE VICKERS . (police-constable L 54.) About seven o'clock in the evening I was on duty, and saw the prisoner standing close behind the pro
secutrix—I did not see him take the purse out of her pocket, but I took his hand from her person, and took this purse out of his hand—he let it fall on the ground.
WILLIAM ROWE (police-sergeant M 10.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, from Mr. Clark's office (read)—the prisoner is the man.

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Transported For Fourteen Years.

2015.
WILLIAM MATTHEWS was indicted
for stealing, on the 12th of August, 12 umbrellas, value 2l., the goods of
Thomas Evans.

ELIZA BRUCE . I am in the employ of Thomas Evans. On the 12th of August, I was taking twelve umbrellas to him, Silver-street, at eight o'clock in the evening—I put them in the passage, where we always put the work, by the warehouse-door, and sat down about half a yard from them—my attention was called by a young woman, and they were gone—I went after a man in white trowsers, who had come into the passage—I spoke to him, and said, "You have got my work"—he said something—I saw the prisoner in Addle-street, and saw him drop my umbrellas—he was running at the time—I hallooed out, "Stop thief"—he was stopped, but not in my presence—the umbrellas were picked up, and given to me—I was about four yards from the prisoner, on the other side of the road, at the time—I saw him again in about ten minutes.

THOMAS FREESTON KIRBY . I live in Addle-street. On the evening of the 12th of August I saw the prisoner in Addle-street, with a bundle of umbrellas—he was running—I saw him drop them—I heard the prosecutrix cry, "Stop thief," and ran after him till he was taken, by a person, at the end of Philip-lane, and given to an officer—he had run about two hundred yards after dropping them, and turned a corner—I was so close to him, and did not lose sight of him.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you keep sight of him all the time? A. Yes—the person who took him is not here—he was given into the custody of an officer—I was about thirty yards from him when he

was stopped—the moment he dropped the umbrellas, he ran away so fast it was almost impossible any body could run so swift—the corner is not twenty yards from where he dropped the umbrellas—he had dark trowsers on—I had never seen him before.

FRANCIS EARL . I am a constable of Cripplegate. I heard the cry of "Stop thief" and saw the prisoner running down Phillip-lane—I endea
voured to stop him, but missed my hold—I turned round and pursued him—another person, a stranger, caught hold of him—I came up almost imme
diately and secured him—Kirby came to the station-house directly after
wards—I did not notice him before.

Cross-examined. Q. He did not come up where the prisoner was stop
ped? A. I did notice—him—there were a great many people there.

THOMAS EVAN . I am the employer of Bruce—the umbrellas are mine. Cross-examined. Q. What are you? A. A wholesale umbrella-manu
facturer—these are not finished, but they are complete enough to answer the purpose of umbrellas.

Prisoner's Defence. I was returning from my master's—I went to my mother's and on coming back, I was going to Billingsgate to assist my wife home, and on the road in Wood-street I heard a cry of "Stop thief"—I ran with the other people—a man in white trowsers was running, and that man let the bundle fall out of his arm—I turned one way, and suppose the man went the other—as soon as I turned the corner I was laid hold of—four or five people came to the station-house, and said I was not the man who dropped it, that it was a person in white trowsers; but they were all pushed away from the door—the door was shut in their faces—they pro
mised to come forward, but I do not know whether they are here.

MARY ANN FORD . I live in Phillip-lane, my husband works in Al
dersgate-street. I was in Silver-street on the 12th of August, and as I came across from Silver-street, there was a young man with a bundle of umbrellas under his left arm—they were covered with green baize—the young man came across the road, and his right arm touched my left—an umbrella-maker living in our court, made me take notice, and I followed him down opposite the locksmith's—the people came running down the street—he turned his head, saw them running, and threw down the umbrellas in the gutter, a few yards from me—I did not go to the watch-house when the prisoner was taken—I do not know him—the man had dirty looking white trowsers on—the prisoner is not the young man I saw throw down the umbrellas—I cannot say it was not him—I saw no features because I was behind him, but I am sure he had dirty looking white trowsers—when they were thrown down there was a cry of "Stop thief"—there were several persons standing who might have taken him, but I could not see his face.

JAMES BOLTON . I am an appraiser, and live in Addle-street. On the 12th of August, I was returning home from Aldermanbury—I had arrived near the end of Phillip-lane, when I heard the cry of "Stop thief", and immediately afterwards saw two men run past me, one in white trowsers, and the other in dark—the one in white trowsers was on the right hand side, and the other on the left—I turned after them, and went down to the end of the street—they then parted, the man in white trowsers to the right, and the other to the left—two girls were following them—I returned towards my own home, and when I got to Philip-lane, I found somebody in custody—I then went to the station-house, and was refused admission—I really cannot say whether the prisoner was either of those men.

THOMAS KIRBY
re-examined There were two men running—one in white trowsers, and the prisoner in dark trowsers—I stopped the man in white trowers because he was nearest to me—he said, "It is not me," and I saw the prisoner with the bundle under his arm—I let the man in white trowsers go—and followed the prisoner and saw him drop the bundle.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Why not tell his Lordship in the first instance that you stopped the man in white trowsers? A. The question was not put to me.
JOHN BOLTON . No one was passing, no one pursued or stopped the man in white trowsers I solemnly declare—nobody could stop from the end of Phillip-lane to Aldermanbury.

THOMAS KIRBY
re-examined. It was in Addle-street I stopped him—the man who dropped the umbrellas was not twenty yards from me at the time—I did not lose sight of him till he was taken—the other took the right hand side, and this man the left, and I took him—he is the man who was taken to the station-house.

ELIZA BRUCE
re-examined. I saw the prisoner drop the umbrella—I did not see the face, but he is the person—I spoke to the man with white trowsers and said, "You have got my work," he said, "No; it is not me, I have not got your work"—so I turned my head, and saw this man running with them—the man in white trowsers came into the passage, and I thought it was him at first, and followed, and spoke to him.
THOMAS KIRBY . He dropped the umbrellas before he turned the corner—that was the time he gained ground on me—I positively did not lose sight of him—I saw the prisoner at the station-house.

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Four Months.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, THE 19TH OF SEPTEMBER
